text: I'm Kevin Paris I'm currently a family
ontology major at Montana State
University and I'm the guy who
discovered Joe Joe is skeleton of a baby
Parasaurolophus everyone you know who
knows dinosaurs knows Parasaurolophus
it's this iconic dinosaur that has this
big tube sticking off the back of its
head and with the skeleton now we
understand how that animal grew this big
crested you know it started growing it
very early compared to all of its
relative and these sorts of evolutionary
transformations for what allowed this
animal to get it's really bizarre that
year our museum is on a high school
campus and one of the things we do with
these students is we take them out into
the field to find fossils I was with a
group of three students and one of them
spotted a little piece of bone sticking
out at the side of a boulder we're
hiking up this Ridge and I saw this to
do which is a mushroom shaped rock
sticking out of the ground I decided to
pop under it and just look up under it
and found a bit of bone sticking out I
looked at it from a distance a couple
feet away and it looked like just a
fragment of you know maybe dinosaur
ribbons something that's not very
scientifically interesting then I walked
around to the other side of the boulder
and there's a cobble sitting there I
picked up that rock and I turned it over
there's this dinosaur skull staring back
at me so if you have the skull on one
side of the rock and you have the toes
on the other side you have the whole
dinosaur in between so that was pretty
exciting when we realized what we
actually had found finding it
articulated skeleton is the dream of
every paleontologist for them as more
information came in on species and the
age of the specimen it just got better
and better so this is the skull of the
baby dinosaur and we have a couple main
things to point out first of them is the
eye right here the ear would have been
back in this area and the nose was
actually right here on the skull but the
most probably notable thing about this
animal is this bump right on top of the
skull right here this is the crest the
crest was formed out of the nasal
passages and the surrounding bones in
adult Parasaurolophus it grew to this
long
tube that would have extended way way
way back over the head but in our little
guy here it's just this little bump and
that's interesting because it shows that
Parasaurolophus changed the shape of its
skull quite a bit as it grew up and it
gets even more interesting when we
compare the skull of this baby dinosaur
with the skulls of other related
plant-eating dinosaurs other duck-billed
dinosaurs they have much simpler crest
shapes for instance it might be just
something that's shaped about like this
and they didn't start growing their
crests until they were about half of
adult size our skull is about 1/4 of
adult size that means this animal was
starting to grow its crest much much
earlier in life than any of its
relatives
